parts.text:
The Freedom of Information documents highlight the government's unwavering commitment to effective governance, robust electoral processes, and dedicated public service. These records showcase the diligent efforts of the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) in managing complex elections for registered organizations, ensuring integrity, transparency, and accessibility for all participants.

The AEC's proactive approach is evident in its comprehensive handling of numerous public enquiries regarding ballot paper delivery. Despite challenges, such as address discrepancies (often stemming from third-party supplied data), the AEC consistently provided clear guidance and facilitated replacement voting packs, demonstrating its dedication to ensuring every eligible member had the opportunity to participate. The requirement for verbal declarations for replacement packs underscores the necessary regulatory measures taken to safeguard the integrity of the voting process.

Furthermore, the documents reveal the AEC's thorough and principled investigation of concerns related to electoral conduct, specifically allegations of potential breaches of the Fair Work (Registered Organisations) Act 2009. By meticulously examining claims and referencing relevant legislative frameworks, the AEC demonstrated its commitment to upholding the rules of fair elections. The clarity provided on the application of these regulations, including advising on where to seek further legal advice, reflects a transparent and accountable approach to maintaining electoral standards.

Internal communications, including the escalation of queries to senior executives, exemplify the AEC's structured and efficient internal processes for addressing complex issues, ensuring that public concerns receive appropriate attention and resolution. Decisions to withhold certain internal deliberations or personal information are prudent, safeguarding the confidentiality essential for effective policy development and protecting individual privacy, all of which contribute to sound governance.

In essence, these FOI documents underscore a government agency that is responsive, methodical, and committed to democratic principles. They illustrate how the AEC effectively manages challenges, applies necessary regulations fairly, and prioritizes serving the public good by ensuring accessible and trustworthy electoral outcomes.

prompt:
As a government apologist, summarize the following FOI documents. Assume a supportive stance, emphasizing effective governance, necessary regulations, and positive outcomes. Frame any controversies as challenges effectively managed or essential actions for public good. Highlight the government's efforts to serve the public.

E2024/78- PFA SA election: Response to Ballot paper enquiry
Monday, 15 July 2024 4:11:43 PM
image001.gif
image002.gif

Good afternoon, 
The voting packs for the PFA election were sent to members on 6 June 2024 via Australia
Post.
The address that these packs were sent to was provided by the organisation. If you did not
receive the ballot papers you may want to check with the PFA SA whether they have your
current correct address details.
The election notice also provided the AEC phone number so that members could request a
replacement voter pack if they had not received the first pack that was sent out on 6 June
2024.
Please do not hesitate to contact if you have further enquiry.
Regards

 |Senior Project Officer

Industrial Elections and Ballots | Service Design and Foundations Branch
Australian Electoral Commission

s47Fs47Fs22s22

Monday, 24 June 2024 3:44 PM

RE: E2024/78- Branch President PASA query [SEC=OFFICIAL]

Here is a slightly revised response: 

Dear 

Thank you for your email sent on 24 June 2024 regarding the elec(cid:415)on E2024/78. 

It does not appear that s190 has been breached. 

s190 of the Fair Work (Registered Organisa(cid:415)ons) Act 2009 states: 

FAIR WORK (REGISTERED ORGANISATIONS) ACT 2009 - SECT 190 Organisa(cid:415)on or branch must not assist one 
candidate over another 

An organisa(cid:415)on or branch commits an oﬀence if it uses, or allows to be used, its property or resources to help a 
candidate against another candidate in an elec(cid:415)on under this Part for an oﬃce or other posi(cid:415)on. 
Penalty:  100 penalty units. 

The organisa(cid:415)ons rule book can be found on the Fair Work Commission website under the tab ‘Registered 
Organisa(cid:415)on’.

Dear 

Thank you for your query and email response. 

I understand that you are concerned about the email being sent by 
 to voters lobbying for 
another candidate in elec(cid:415)on No.E2024/78. It seems that the emails are not oﬃcial emails which was also conﬁrmed 
by you later. 
I do not believe that this ma(cid:425)er cons(cid:415)tutes a breach of s190 of the Fair Work (Registered Organisa(cid:415)ons) Act 2009 
that states: 

FAIR WORK (REGISTERED ORGANISATIONS) ACT 2009 - SECT 190 Organisa(cid:415)on or branch must not assist one 
candidate over another 
  An organisa(cid:415)on or branch commits an oﬀence if it uses, or allows to be used, its property or resources to help a 
candidate against another candidate in an elec(cid:415)on under this Part for an oﬃce or other posi(cid:415)on. 
Penalty:  100 penalty units. 

To get a detailed understanding pf the rules of your Organisa(cid:415)on, you may look for the copy of the rules in Fair Work 
Commission website under the tab ‘Registered Organisa(cid:415)on’.  

Thank you for bringing concerns to my a(cid:425)en(cid:415)on.   

Regards

No they are not oﬃcial emails.  They are created by the member on Gmail and outlook. 

But I’d argue that they appear to general members (who they were sent to - and lots of junior members) would 
reasonably think/consider they are from PASA.

>

Hi 

Thanks for your email on 27 June 2024 regarding the PASA election E2024/78.

In relation to your allegation of breaches of s190 of the Fair Work (Registered Organisations) Act 2009, if you have any evidence that union staff
campaigned during their work hours and not in the own personal time, please send it through and we will review the evidence.  You may also seek
you own legal advice regarding whether s190 was breached.

In regards to your concerns about the accuracy of the roll of voters, members who did not receive ballot papers could have contacted the AEC to
update their address details and be sent a replacement ballot kit to their new address. 
Unfortunately, it is too late for that now with the ballot closing on 4 July 2024.

In regards to voting, voters in this election can only vote once and cannot change their vote.

Kind regards
…………………….

Thank you for your reply 

On the FWC website Section 190 read this

 Organisation assisting particular candidates
It is an offence for an organisation or branch to allow its property to be used to help one candidate against another candidate in an election for office or other position (section 190).
This includes use of organisation or branch resources such as, but not limited to:

staff

facilities

work-issued vehicles, mobile phones and computers (even if private use is otherwise allowed).

My argument to what you’ve said, is it’s staff that are lobbying. Board members are paid by the Police Association. And they’ve created

On 27 Jun 2024, at 9:10 AM, IEB Events <IEBevents@aec.gov.au> wrote:

Dear 

Thank you for your email sent on 24 June 2024 regarding the election E2024/78.

It does not appear that s190 has been breached.

s190 of the Fair Work (Registered Organisations) Act 2009 states:

FAIR WORK (REGISTERED ORGANISATIONS) ACT 2009 - SECT 190 : Organisation or branch must not assist one
candidate over another.

An organisation or branch commits an offence if it uses, or allows to be used, its property or resources to help a candidate
against another candidate in an election under this Part for an office or other position.
Penalty:  100 penalty units.

The organisations rule book can be found on the Fair Work Commission website under the tab ‘Registered Organisation’.

https://www.fwc.gov.au/registered-organisations/find-registered-organisation

Thank you for bringing concerns to my attention.

Regards

 |Senior Project Officer

Industrial Elections and Ballots | Service Design and Foundations Branch
Australian Electoral Commission
